member.name: T:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade
member.summary: Simplifies authoring for major upgrades, including support for preventing downgrades.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.Default
F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.AllowDowngrades
member.summary:
When set to "false" (the default), products with lower version numbers are blocked from installing when a product with a higher version is installed; the DowngradeErrorMessage attribute must also be specified.
When set to "true", any version can be installed over any other version.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.AllowSameVersionUpgrades
member.summary:
When set to "false" (the default), installing a product with the same version and upgrade code (but different product code) is allowed and treated by MSI as two products. When set to yes, WiX sets the msidbUpgradeAttributesVersionMaxInclusive attribute, which tells MSI to treat a product with the same version as a major upgrade.
This is useful when two product versions differ only in the fourth version field. MSI specifically ignores that field when comparing product versions, so two products that differ only in the fourth version field are the same product and need this attribute set to "true" to be detected.
Note that because MSI ignores the fourth product version field, setting this attribute to yes also allows downgrades when the first three product version fields are identical. For example, product version 1.0.0.1 will "upgrade" 1.0.0.2998 because they're seen as the same version (1.0.0). That could reintroduce serious bugs so the safest choice is to change the first three version fields and omit this attribute to get the default of no.
This attribute cannot be "true" when AllowDowngrades is also "true" -- AllowDowngrades already allows two products with the same version number to upgrade each other.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.Disallow
F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.DisallowUpgradeErrorMessage
member.summary: The message displayed if users try to install a product with a higher version number when a product with a lower version is installed. Used only when Disallow is "true".

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.DowngradeErrorMessage
member.summary: The message displayed if users try to install a product with a lower version number when a product with a higher version is installed. Used only when AllowDowngrades is "false" (the default).

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.IgnoreRemoveFailure
member.summary: When set to "true", failures removing the installed product during the upgrade will be ignored. When set to "false" (the default), failures removing the installed product during the upgrade will be considered a failure and, depending on the scheduling, roll back the upgrade.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.MigrateFeatures
member.summary:
When set to "true" (the default), the MigrateFeatureStates standard action will set the feature states of the upgrade product to those of the installed product.
When set to "false", the installed features have no effect on the upgrade installation

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.RemoveFeatures
member.summary: A formatted string that contains the list of features to remove from the installed product. The default is to remove all features. Note that if you use formatted property values that evaluate to an empty string, no features will be removed; only omitting this attribute defaults to removing all features.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.Schedule
member.summary: Determines the scheduling of the RemoveExistingProducts standard action, which is when the installed product is removed. The default is "afterInstallValidate" which removes the installed product entirely before installing the upgrade product. It's slowest but gives the most flexibility in changing components and features in the upgrade product.

member.name: M:WixSharp.MajorUpgrade.ToXml
member.summary: Emits WiX XML.

member.name: T:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule
member.summary: Determines the scheduling of the RemoveExistingProducts standard action.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule.afterInstallValidate
member.summary: (Default) Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallValidate standard action. This scheduling removes the installed product entirely before installing the upgrade product. It's slowest but gives the most flexibility in changing components and features in the upgrade product. Note that if the installation of the upgrade product fails, the machine will have neither version installed.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule.afterInstallInitialize
member.summary: Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallInitialize standard action. This is similar to the afterInstallValidate scheduling, but if the installation of the upgrade product fails, Windows Installer also rolls back the removal of the installed product -- in other words, reinstalls it.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule.afterInstallExecute
member.summary: Schedules RemoveExistingProducts between the InstallExecute and InstallFinalize standard actions. This scheduling installs the upgrade product "on top of" the installed product then lets RemoveExistingProducts uninstall any components that don't also exist in the upgrade product. Note that this scheduling requires strict adherence to the component rules because it relies on component reference counts to be accurate during installation of the upgrade product and removal of the installed product. For more information, see Bob Arnson's blog post "Paying for Upgrades" for details. If installation of the upgrade product fails, Windows Installer also rolls back the removal of the installed product -- in other words, reinstalls it.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule.afterInstallExecuteAgain
member.summary: Schedules RemoveExistingProducts between the InstallExecuteAgain and InstallFinalize standard actions. This is identical to the afterInstallExecute scheduling but after the InstallExecuteAgain standard action instead of InstallExecute.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UpgradeSchedule.afterInstallFinalize
member.summary: Schedules RemoveExistingProducts after the InstallFinalize standard action. This is similar to the afterInstallExecute and afterInstallExecuteAgain schedulings but takes place outside the installation transaction so if installation of the upgrade product fails, Windows Installer does not roll back the removal of the installed product, so the machine will have both versions installed.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Media
F:WixSharp.Media.Id
member.summary: Disk identifier for Media table. This number must be equal to or greater than 1.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.Cabinet
member.summary:
The name of the cabinet if some or all of the files stored on the media are in a cabinet file. If no cabinets are used, this attribute must not be set.
The default value is "{projectId}.cab", which is expanded ar runtime

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.CompressionLevel
member.summary: Indicates the compression level for the Media's cabinet. This attribute can only be used in conjunction with the Cabinet attribute. The default is 'mszip'.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.DiskPrompt
member.summary: The disk name, which is usually the visible text printed on the disk. This localizable text is used to prompt the user when this disk needs to be inserted. This value will be used in the "[1]" of the DiskPrompt Property. Using this attribute will require you to define a DiskPrompt Property.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.EmbedCab
member.summary: Instructs the binder to embed the cabinet in the product if 'yes'. This attribute can only be specified in conjunction with the Cabinet attribute.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.Layout
member.summary: This attribute specifies the root directory for the uncompressed files that are a part of this Media element. By default, the src will be the output directory for the final image. The default value ensures the binder generates an installable image. If a relative path is specified in the src attribute, the value will be appended to the image's output directory. If an absolute path is provided, that path will be used without modification. The latter two options are provided to ease the layout of an image onto multiple medias (CDs/DVDs).

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.Source
member.summary: Optional property that identifies the source of the embedded cabinet. If a cabinet is specified for a patch, this property should be defined and unique to each patch so that the embedded cabinet containing patched and new files can be located in the patch package. If the cabinet is not embedded - this is not typical - the cabinet can be found in the directory referenced in this column. If empty, the external cabinet must be located in the SourceDir directory.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Media.VolumeLabel
member.summary: The label attributed to the volume. This is the volume label returned by the GetVolumeInformation function. If the SourceDir property refers to a removable (floppy or CD-ROM) volume, then this volume label is used to verify that the proper disk is in the drive before attempting to install files. The entry in this column must match the volume label of the physical media.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Media.ToXml(System.String)
member.summary: Emits WiX XML.

member.name: T:WixSharp.MediaTemplate
member.summary:
MediaTeplate element describes information to automatically assign files to cabinets. A maximumum number of cabinets created is 999. The following is an example of defining the MediaTemplate element(s).
var project = new Project("My Product", new MediaTemplate { CompressionLevel=CompressionLevel.high }, new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", ... project.BuildMsi();

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.CabinetTemplate
member.summary: Templated name of the cabinet if some or all of the files stored on the media are in a cabinet file. This name must begin with either a letter or an underscore, contain maximum of five characters and {0} in the cabinet name part and must end three character extension. The default is cab{0}.cab.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.CompressionLevel
member.summary: Indicates the compression level for the Media's cabinet. This attribute can only be used in conjunction with the Cabinet attribute. The default is 'mszip'.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.DiskPrompt
member.summary: The disk name, which is usually the visible text printed on the disk. This localizable text is used to prompt the user when this disk needs to be inserted. This value will be used in the "[1]" of the DiskPrompt Property. Using this attribute will require you to define a DiskPrompt Property.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.EmbedCab
member.summary: Instructs the binder to embed the cabinets in the product if 'true'.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.MaximumCabinetSizeForLargeFileSplitting
member.summary: Maximum size of cabinet files in megabytes for large files. This attribute is used for packaging files that are larger than MaximumUncompressedMediaSize into smaller cabinets. If cabinet size exceed this value, then setting this attribute will cause the file to be split into multiple cabinets of this maximum size. For simply controlling cabinet size without file splitting use MaximumUncompressedMediaSize attribute. Setting this attribute will disable smart cabbing feature for this Fragment / Product. Setting WIX_MCSLFS environment variable can be used to override this value. Minimum allowed value of this attribute is 20 MB. Maximum allowed value and the Default value of this attribute is 2048 MB (2 GB).

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.MaximumUncompressedMediaSize
member.summary: Size of uncompressed files in each cabinet, in megabytes. WIX_MUMS environment variable can be used to override this value. Default value is 200 MB.

member.name: F:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.VolumeLabel
member.summary: The label attributed to the volume. This is the volume label returned by the GetVolumeInformation function. If the SourceDir property refers to a removable (floppy or CD-ROM) volume, then this volume label is used to verify that the proper disk is in the drive before attempting to install files. The entry in this column must match the volume label of the physical media.

member.name: M:WixSharp.MediaTemplate.Process(WixSharp.ProcessingContext)
member.summary: Adds itself as an XML content into the WiX source being generated from the . See 'Wix#/samples/Extensions' sample for the details on how to implement this interface correctly.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapper
member.summary:
Defines native (un-managed) bootstrapper. The bootstrapper is created by the NSIS installer authoring tool. The path to NSIS installation is detected through the WIXSHARP_NSISDIR environment variable or installation in the default "%ProgramFiles(x86)%\NSIS" location. The primary usage of is to build bootstrappers for automatically installing .NET for executing MSIs containing managed Custom Actions ().
NsisBootstrapper is subject to the following limitations:
Only Win32 native bootstrapper can be built.
Only one Prerequisite cen be defined.

member.summary: Describes a prerequisite package.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.Primary
member.summary: Describes a primary package.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrerequisiteFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the prerequisite file. Executables and .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, .js scripts are supported.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrimaryFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the primary setup file. Executables and .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, .js scripts are supported.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrerequisiteRegKeyValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prerequisite registry key value. This value is used to determine if the file should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication that the file has been already installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute file without launching file first.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite
member.summary:
Gets or sets the flag which allows you to disable verification of after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checkes if exists stright after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
member.value: The do not post verify prerequisite.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrerequisiteFileOptionName
member.summary: Gets or sets command line option name for the prerequisite file.
member.value: The option name of the prerequisite file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrimaryFileOptionName
member.summary: Gets or sets command line option name for the primary file.
member.value: The option name of the primary file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrerequisiteFileArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets preset command line arguments for the prerequisite file.
member.value: The preset command line arguments of the prerequisite file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.NsisBootstrapperLegacy.PrimaryFileArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets preset command line arguments for the primary file.
member.value: The preset command line arguments of the primary file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.PrerequisitePackage.RegKeyValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prerequisite registry key value. This value is used to determine if the prerequisite file should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. Prerequisite.RegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication that the prerequisite file has been already installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute the primary file without launching the prerequisite file first.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Nsis.PrerequisitePackage.PostVerify
member.summary:
Gets or sets the flag which allows you to disable verification of after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checks if exists straight after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting PostVerify to false (default is true)

Represents an ODBCDataSource to be registered.
The following is an example of using ODBCDataSource.

new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", ...
new ODBCDataSource("DsnName", "SQL Server", true, true, new Property("Database", "MyDb"), new Property("Server", "MyServer")),
...

member.name: T:WixSharp.RebootSupressing
member.summary:
Value of the REBOOT property. The REBOOT property suppresses certain prompts for a restart of the system. An administrator typically uses this property with a series of installations to install several products at the same time with only one restart at the end. For more information, see System Reboots.
The ForceReboot and ScheduleReboot actions inform the installer to prompt the user to restart the system. The installer can also determine that a restart is necessary whether there are any ForceReboot or ScheduleReboot actions in the sequence. For example, the installer automatically prompts for a restart if it needs to replace any files in use during the installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RebootSupressing.Force
member.summary: Always prompt for a restart at the end of the installation. The UI always prompts the user with an option to restart at the end. If there is no user interface, and this is not a multiple-package installation, the system automatically restarts at the end of the installation. If this is a multiple-package installation, there is no automatic restart of the system and the installer returns ERROR_SUCCESS_REBOOT_REQUIRED.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RebootSupressing.Suppress
member.summary: Suppress prompts for a restart at the end of the installation. The installer still prompts the user with an option to restart during the installation whenever it encounters the ForceReboot action. If there is no user interface, the system automatically restarts at each ForceReboot. Restarts at the end of the installation (for example, caused by an attempt to install a file in use) are suppressed.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RebootSupressing.ReallySuppress
member.summary: Suppress all restarts and restart prompts initiated by ForceReboot during the installation. Suppress all restarts and restart prompts at the end of the installation. Both the restart prompt and the restart itself are suppressed. For example, restarts at the end of the installation, caused by an attempt to install a file in use, are suppressed.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ForceReboot
member.summary: Prompts the user for a restart of the system during the installation. Special actions don't have a built-in sequence number and thus must appear relative to another action. The suggested way to do this is by using the Before or After attribute. InstallExecute and InstallExecuteAgain can optionally appear anywhere between InstallInitialize and InstallFinalize.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.Step
member.summary: Defines at what the action should be executed during the installation.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.When
member.summary: Defines order the action should be executed with respect to the action .

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.Suppress
member.summary: If true, this action will not occur.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.Condition
member.summary: Text node specifies the condition of the action.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.InstallSequence
member.summary: The parent install sequence. The only available sequence for this element is InstallExecuteSequence.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ForceReboot.Overridable
member.summary: If true, the sequencing of this action may be overridden by sequencing elsewhere.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ScheduleReboot
member.summary: Prompts the user to restart the system at the end of installation. Special actions don't have a built-in sequence number and thus must appear relative to another action. The suggested way to do this is by using the Before or After attribute. InstallExecute and InstallExecuteAgain can optionally appear anywhere between InstallInitialize and InstallFinalize.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ScheduleReboot.InstallSequence
member.summary: Indicates what install sequence should ScheduleReboot be placed to.

member.name: T:WixSharp.RegistrySearchType
member.summary: The value must be 'file' if the child is a FileSearch element, and must be 'directory' if child is a DirectorySearch element. This attribute's value must be one of the following:

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearchType.directory
member.summary: The registry value contains the path to a directory.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearchType.file
member.summary: The registry value contains the path to a file. To return the full file path you must add a FileSearch element as a child of this element; otherwise, the parent directory of the file path is returned.

summary.para: Sets the raw value from the registry value. Please note that this value will contain a prefix as follows:
DWORD: Starts with '#' optionally followed by '+' or '-'.
REG_BINARY: Starts with '#x' and the installer converts and saves each hexadecimal digit (nibble) as an ASCII character prefixed by '#x'.
REG_MULTI_SZ: Starts with '[~]' and ends with '[~]'.
REG_SZ: No prefix, but if the first character of the registry value is '#', the installer escapes the character by prefixing it with another '#'.

member.name: P:WixSharp.RegistrySearch.Id
member.summary: Signature to be used for the file, directory or registry key being searched for.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearch.Name
member.summary: Registry value name. If this value is null, then the value from the key's unnamed or default value, if any, is retrieved.

member.summary:
Root key for the registry value.This attribute's value must be one of the following:
- ClassesRoot
- CurrentUser
- LocalMachine
- Users

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearch.Key
member.summary: Key for the registry value.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearch.Type
member.summary: The value must be 'file' if the child is a FileSearch element, and must be 'directory' if child is a DirectorySearch element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.RegistrySearch.Win64
member.summary: Instructs the search to look in the 64-bit registry when the value is 'true'. When the value is 'false', the search looks in the 32-bit registry. The default value is based on the platform set by the -arch switch to candle.exe or the InstallerPlatform property in a .wixproj MSBuild project: For x86 and ARM, the default value is 'false'. For x64 and IA64, the default value is 'true'.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ResilientPackage
member.summary:
Allows to repair the MSI package even when the original installation package is no longer available.
Adds an additional source of the resiliency by attempting to create a symbolic link to the locally cached MSI package (%WINDIR%\Installer) or a hard link/full copy to the original installation MSI package in the specified directory.
WIXSHARP_RESILIENT_SOURCE_DIR property can be used to configure the target directory. INSTALLDIR property is used by default.
Windows 7 is shipped with the Windows Installer version 5.0, which unlike the previous versions of the windows installer caches the entire MSI, including internal CAB files. Unfortunately the complete cached MSI package is not used for repairs, a call is made to the original source which might not be available.
See also:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/msi/source-resiliency
https://www.symantec.com/connect/articles/reducing-windows-installer-disk-wastage-windows-7

member.name: M:WixSharp.ResilientPackage.EnableResilientPackage(WixSharp.Project)
member.summary: Enables source resiliency for the installer. Creates a symbolic link/hard link or makes a copy of the original MSI package in the specified location and points SOURCELIST to it.

member.name: M:WixSharp.ResilientPackage.EnableResilientPackage(WixSharp.Project,System.String)
member.summary: Enables source resiliency for the installer. Creates a symbolic link/hard link or makes a copy of the original MSI package in the specified location and points SOURCELIST to it.

member.summary: Internal ResilientPackage action. It must be public for the DTF accessibility but it is not to be used by the user/developer.

member.summary: Internal ResilientPackage action. It must be public for the DTF accessibility but it is not to be used by the user/developer.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ServiceConfig
member.summary: Configures a service being installed or one that already exists. This element's functionality is available starting with MSI 5.0.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.DelayedAutoStart
member.summary: Specifies whether an auto-start service should delay its start until after all other auto-start services. This property only affects auto-start services. If this property is not initialized the setting is not configured.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.PreShutdownDelay
member.summary: Specifies time in milliseconds that the Service Control Manager (SCM) waits after notifying the service of a system shutdown. If this attribute is not present the default value, 3 minutes, is used.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.ServiceSid

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.OnReinstall
member.summary: Specifies whether to configure the service when the parent Component is reinstalled.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.OnUninstall
member.summary: Specifies whether to configure the service when the parent Component is uninstalled.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ServiceConfig.ConfigureServiceTrigger
member.summary: Specifies whether to configure the service when the parent Component is installed, reinstalled, or uninstalled
member.remarks: Defaults to ConfigureServiceTrigger.Install. Strictly applies to the configuration of properties: DelayedAutoStart, PreShutdownDelay, ServiceSid.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.AsWixVarToPath(System.String)
member.summary:
'Interprets' a string as a WiX constant and expands into a proper File System path. For example "DesktopFolder" will be expanded into "[SysDrive]:\Users\[user]\Desktop". This method is a logical equivalent of C# Environment.GetFolderPath. Though it handles discrepancies between 'special folders' mapping in .NET and WiX.
The method will always be called from x86 runtime as MSI always loads ManagedUI in x86 host. From the other hand CustomActions are called in the deployment specific CPU type context.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Expand(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
It also replaces all "illegal" characters (e.g. !,\) with '_' character to allow the path value to be used as a WiX Id XML attribute.The following is an example of expanding directory name paths.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyses WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.
member.param: if set to true starting from digit character is permitted.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ContainsWixConstants(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the string contains WiX constants (values enclosed into square brackets).

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsWixConstant(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the value is a WiX constant (e.g. 'SystemFolder').
member.returns: true if the specified value is a WiX constant; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Map64Dirs(System.String)
member.summary:
Maps the Wix# constants included in path into their x64 equivalents.
For example %ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product should be preprocessed into %ProgramFiles64%\My Company\My Product

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ExpandWixEnvConsts(System.String)
member.summary:
Replaces all Wix# predefined string constants (Environment Constants) in the Wix# directory path with their WiX equivalents and escapes all WiX illegal characters (e.g. space character).
The following is an example of expanding directory name paths.
@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"ProgramFilesFolder\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product" @"[ProgramFilesFolder]\My Company\My Product".Expand() -> @"ProgramFilesFolder\My_Company\My_Product"
For the list of supported constants analyse WixSharp.Compiler.EnvironmentConstantsMapping.Keys.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.NormalizeWixString(System.String)
member.summary:
Normalizes the wix environment constants and custom properties.
This method is not the same as `ExpandWixEnvConsts`. The key difference is that it handles custom properties, leaves square brackets unchanged and also normalizes directory separators. Normalization is critical for string values that are used as `ExeFileShortcut.Target`:
@"%INSTALLDIR%\my_app.exe".NormalizeWixString() -> "[INSTALLDIR]my_app.exe" @"%INSTALLDIR%my_app.exe".NormalizeWixString() -> "[INSTALLDIR]my_app.exe" @"[INSTALLDIR]my_app.exe".NormalizeWixString() -> "[INSTALLDIR]my_app.exe"

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.UnEscapeEnvars(System.String)
member.summary:
Unescape '\%' characters in the tokens representing environment variables (e.g. "%ProgramFiles%\My Product").
Required for avoiding collisions between environment variables and WiX constants. For example to prevent "%ProgramFiles%\My Product" being later converted into "ProgramFilesFolder\My Product"

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.EscapeEnvars(System.String)
member.summary:
Escape '%' characters in the tokens representing environment variables (e.g. "%ProgramFiles%\My Product").
Required for avoiding collisions between environment variables and WiX constants. For example to prevent "%ProgramFiles%\My Product" being later converted into "ProgramFilesFolder\My Product"

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsActive(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Determines whether the specified is active.
It is useful for checking if the session is terminated (e.g. in deferred custom actions).

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsInstalled(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Determines whether the product associated with the session is installed.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsUISupressed(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether Authored UI and wizard dialog boxes suppressed.
member.value: true if UI is suppressed; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.UILevel(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Gets the UIlevel.
UILevel > 4 lead to displaying modal dialogs. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa369487(v=vs.85).aspx.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsInstalling(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Gets a value indicating whether the product is being installed.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.GetMainWindow(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Gets the main window of the msiexec.exe process that has 'MainWindowTitle' containing the name of the product being installed.
This method is a convenient way to display message box from a custom action with properly specified parent window.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsRepairing(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Gets a value indicating whether the product is being repaired.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsUpgrading(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Gets a value indicating whether the product is being upgraded.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.
This method relies on "UPGRADINGPRODUCTCODE" property, which is not set by MSI until previous version is uninstalled. Thus it may not be the most practical way of detecting upgrades. Use AppSearch.GetProductVersionFromUpgradeCode as a more reliable alternative.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsModifying(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Determines whether MSI is running in "modifying" mode.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsUninstalling(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Determines whether MSI is running in "uninstalling" mode.
This method will fail to retrieve the correct value if called from the deferred custom action and the session properties that it depends on are not preserved with 'UsesProperties' or 'DefaultUsesProperties'.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IfEmptyUse(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the first string `value1` if it is not empty. Otherwise returns `value2`.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsFeatureEnabled(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the feature is selected in the feature tree of the Features dialog and will be installed. The "selected" state of the feature is determined by analysing the `ADDLOCAL` session property, which has the required information either feature selected via UI or via msiexec.exe CLI arguments. If none of this selections is made by the user the method will return the default state of the feature (from session property "ADDFEATURES").

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.InitFeaturesFromCurrentInstallation(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Sets `ADDLOCAL` session property to the coma-delimited values of the all features currently installed. This method is useful if you want to initialize current session with the specific features enabled according the previous installation if found. Applicable only for Major Upgrade scenarios.
Managed UI does this automatically but if you suppress UI then you may want to do this manually. Then this method is to do the heavy lifting.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.BeingInstall(WixSharp.Feature)
member.summary: Builds an MSI condition expression for the given , which evaluates as true if the feature is being installed.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ShallInstall(WixSharp.Feature)
member.summary: Creates a condition that checks if the feature shall be installed regardless of whether it already is intalled

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ShallUninstall(WixSharp.Feature)
member.summary: Creates a condition that checks if the feature shall be uninstalled regardless of whether it already is intalled

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.ToItems(WixSharp.Feature)
member.summary: Agregate all items.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.BeingUninstall(WixSharp.Feature)
member.summary: Builds an MSI condition expression for the given , which evaluates as true if the feature is being uninstalled.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsBasic(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.InstallUIOptions)
member.summary: Determines whether this is basic UI level.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.Property(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session,System.String)
member.summary:
Returns the value of the named property of the specified object.
It can be uses as a generic way of accessing the properties as it redirects (transparently) access to the if the session is terminated (e.g. in deferred custom actions).

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsCancelled(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified session is cancelled.
member.returns: true if the specified session is cancelled; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.IsCancelledRaw(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session)
member.summary:
Determines whether the specified session is cancelled.
It is identical to except it does not throw/handle internal exception This helps if it is preferred to keep MSI log clean from any messages triggered by handled exceptions.
Though this method relies on internal (non-public) implementation thus is not warranteed to stay unchanged in the future WiX releases.
member.returns: true if the specified session is cancelled; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Extensions.QueryProperty(Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller.Session,System.String)
member.summary: Queries MSI database directly for the table 'Property' value. This method is particularly useful for the stages when WiX session object is not fully initialized. For example properties are not discovered yet during EmbeddedUI loading event.

member.name: T:WixSharp.UrlAce
member.summary: The security principal and which rights to assign to them for the URL reservation.

member.name: P:WixSharp.UrlAce.Id
member.summary: Primary key used to identify this particular entry.

member.name: F:WixSharp.UrlAce.Rights
member.summary:
Rights for this ACE. Default is "all". This attribute's value must be one of the following:
register
delegate
all

member.name: F:WixSharp.UrlAce.SecurityPrincipal
member.summary:
The security principal for this ACE. When the UrlReservation is under a ServiceInstall element, this defaults to "NT SERVICE\ServiceInstallName". This may be either a SID or an account name in a format that LookupAccountName supports. When using a SID, an asterisk must be prepended.
"*S-1-5-18"

member.name: F:WixSharp.User.WixIncludeInComponent
member.summary:
Requests that the User element is included inside a Component element - allowing the User to be installed. If any of the following properties are assigned (non-null), this property is ignored during compilation and assumed to be true:
CanNotChangePassword
CreateUser
Disabled
FailIfExists
LogonAsBatchJob
LogonAsService
PasswordExpired
PasswordNeverExpires
RemoveOnUninstall
UpdateIfExists
Vital

member.summary:
The location of the config file for Managed Custom Action.
The config file (CustomAction.config) is the file to be passed to the MakeSfxCA.exe when packing the Custom Action assembly.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.CustomActionConfig
member.summary: Resolves user defined config file.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.OutFileName
member.summary: Name of the MSI/MSM file (without extension) to be build.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.OutDir
member.summary: The output directory. The directory where all msi and temporary files should be assembled. The CurrentDirectory will be used if is left unassigned.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.WixNamespaces
member.summary: Collection of XML namespaces (e.g. xmlns:iis="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wix/IIsExtension") to be declared in the XML (WiX project) root.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.WixExtensions
member.summary: Collection of paths to the WiX extensions.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.WxsFiles
member.summary:
Collection of paths to the external wsx files containing Fragment(s).
At the compile time files will be pases to candle.exe but the referencing them fragments in the primary wxs (XML) needs to be done from WixSourceGenerated event handler.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.WixVariables
member.summary: This element exposes advanced WiX functionality. Use this element to declare WiX variables from directly within your authoring. WiX variables are not resolved until the final msi/msm/pcp file is actually generated. WiX variables do not persist into the msi/msm/pcp file, so they cannot be used when an MSI file is being installed; it's a WiX-only concept.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.LibFiles
member.summary: Collection of paths to the external wsxlib files to be passed to the Light linker.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.IsMultiLanguage
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this project supports multiple languages.
member.value: true if this project is multi language; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.DefaultLanguage
member.summary: Gets the default language

member.name: P:WixSharp.WixProject.Language
member.summary:
Installation UI Language. If not specified "en-US" will be used.
It is possible to specify multiple languages separated by coma or semicolon. All extra languages will be used as additional values for 'Package.Languages' attribute and light.exe '-cultures:' command line parameters.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.LightOptions
member.summary: WiX linker Light.exe options (e.g. "-sice:ICE30 -sw1076" (disable warning 1076 and ICE warning 30).

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.CandleOptions
member.summary: WiX compiler Candle.exe options (e.g. "-sw1076" to disable warning 1026).

member.name: E:WixSharp.WixProject.WixSourceGenerated
member.summary: Occurs when WiX source code generated. Use this event if you need to modify generated XML (XDocument) before it is compiled into MSI.

member.name: E:WixSharp.WixProject.WixSourceSaved
member.summary: Occurs when WiX source file is saved. Use this event if you need to do any post-processing of the generated/saved file.

member.name: E:WixSharp.WixProject.WixSourceFormated
member.summary: Occurs when WiX source file is formatted and ready to be saved. Use this event if you need to do any custom formatting of the XML content before it is saved by the compiler.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.PreserveTempFiles
member.summary:
Forces to preserve all temporary build files (e.g. *.wxs).
The default value is false: all temporary files are deleted at the end of the build/compilation.
Note: if fails to build MSI the PreserveTempFiles value is ignored and all temporary files are preserved.

member.name: F:WixSharp.WixProject.PreserveDbgFiles
member.summary:
Forces to preserve all obj/pdb build files (e.g. *.wixobj and *.wixpdb).
The default value is false: all temporary files are deleted at the end of the build/compilation.

member.summary: Invokes the WixSourceGenerated event handlers.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.Type
member.summary: The type of the control. Could be one of the following: Billboard, Bitmap, CheckBox, ComboBox, DirectoryCombo, DirectoryList, Edit, GroupBox, Icon, Line, ListBox, ListView, MaskedEdit, PathEdit, ProgressBar, PushButton, RadioButtonGroup, ScrollableText, SelectionTree, Text, VolumeCostList, VolumeSelectCombo. Use constants to define the type of the control.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.X
member.summary: Horizontal coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangular boundary of the control. This must be a non-negative number.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.Y
member.summary: Width of the rectangular boundary of the control. This must be a non-negative number.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.Height
member.summary: Vertical coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangular boundary of the control. This must be a non-negative number.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.Width
member.summary: Width of the rectangular boundary of the control. This must be a non-negative number.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.Control.Text
member.summary: A localizable string used to set the initial text contained in a control. This attribute can contain a formatted string that is processed at install time to insert the values of properties using [PropertyName] syntax. Also supported are environment variables, file installation paths, and component installation directories.

member.summary: The name of a defined property to be linked to this control. This column is required for active controls.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Controls.DialogSequence
member.summary:
Simple class that defines custom UI (WiX UI element). This is a specialized version of class designed to allow simple customization of the dialogs sequence without the introduction of any custom dialogs. The following is an example demonstrates how to skip License Agreement dialog, which is otherwise displayed between Welcome and InstallDir dialogs.
project.CustomUI = new DialogSequence() .On(Dialogs.WelcomeDlg, Buttons.Next, new ShowDialog(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg)) .On(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg, Buttons.Back, new ShowDialog(Dialogs.WelcomeDlg));

member.name: M:WixSharp.Controls.DialogSequence.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Controls.DialogSequence.On(System.String,System.String,WixSharp.Controls.DialogAction[])
member.summary:
Defines the WiX Dialog UI control Action (event handler).
Note that all handlers will have Order field automatically assigned '5' to ensure the overriding the default WiX event handlers

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.DialogSequence.DefaultOrder
member.summary: The default value of the Order of the DialogAction. It is automatically assigned of handler doesn't have it set.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI
member.summary:
Defines custom UI (WiX UI element). This class is to be used to define the customization of the standard MSI UI. The usual scenario of the customization is the injection of the custom into the sequence of the standard dialogs. This can be accomplished by defining the custom dialog as . Such a can be edited with the Visual Studio form designer.
When is complete it can be converted into with the () call. And at compile time Wix# compiler converts into the final WiX UI element XML definition.
While it is possible to construct instance manually it is preferred to use Factory methods of (e.g. BuildPostLicenseDialogUI) for this.
project.UI = WUI.WixUI_Common; project.CustomUI = CustomUIBuilder.BuildPostLicenseDialogUI(productActivationDialog, onNextActions: new DialogAction[]{ new ExecueteCustomAction ("ValidateLicenceKey"), new ShowDialog(Dialogs.InstallDirDlg, "SERIALNUMBER_VALIDATED = \"TRUE\"")});

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.Properties
member.summary: The collection of PropertyId vs. PropertyValue pairs to be defined as the Property WiX elements inside of the UI element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.TextStyles
member.summary: The collection of StyleId vs. Font pairs to be defined as the TextStyle WiX elements inside of the UI element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.DialogRefs
member.summary: The collection of dialog IDs to be defined as the DialogRef WiX elements inside of the UI element. By default it contains references to all MSI predefined dialogs.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.CustomDialogs
member.summary: The collection of s to be defined as the custom Dialog WiX elements inside of the UI element.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.UISequence
member.summary: Defines UI sequence via collection of items containing association between Dialog controls and MSI Dialog actions.

member.name: M:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.On(System.String,System.String,WixSharp.Controls.DialogAction[])
member.summary:
Defines the WiX Dialog UI control Action (event handler).
customUI.On(Dialogs.WelcomeDlg, Buttons.Next, new ShowDialog(Dialogs.LicenseAgreementDlg));

member.name: M:WixSharp.Controls.CustomUI.On(WixSharp.Controls.Dialog,System.String,WixSharp.Controls.DialogAction[])
member.summary:
Defines the UI control Action (event handler).
customUI.On(activationDialog, Buttons.Cancel, new CloseDialog("Exit"));

member.summary: Defines Form designer compatible Condition associated with the WixControl action.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Controls.WixControlCondition.Action
member.summary:
Gets or sets the action.
Used only under Control elements and is required. Allows specific actions to be applied to a control based on the result of this condition. This attribute's value must be one of the following:
- default
- enable
- disable
- hide
- show

member.summary: Gets or sets the value for the action condition of the WiX Control element.

member.name: T:WixSharp.LaunchCondition
member.summary:
Defines WiX Condition. Condition is normally associated with CustomActions or WiX elements (e.g. Shortcut).
is nothing else but an XML friendly string wrapper, containing some predefined (commonly used) condition values. You can either use one of the predefined condition values (static members) or define your by specifying full string representation of the required WiX condition when calling the constructor or static method Create.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ManagedProject
member.summary:
Extends with runtime event-driven behavior ans managed UI (see and ).
The managed project has three very important events that are raised during deployment at run: Load/BeforeInstall/AfterInstall.
ManagedProject still maintains backward compatibility for the all older features. That is why it is important to distinguish the use cases associated with the project class members dedicated to the same problem domain but resolving the problems in different ways:
UI support
project.UI - to be used to define native MSI/WiX UI.
project.CustomUI - to be used for minor to customization of native MSI/WiX UI and injection of CLR dialogs.
project.ManagedUI - to be used to define managed Embedded UI. It allows full customization of the UI
Events
project.WixSourceGenerated
project.WixSourceFormated
project.WixSourceSaved - to be used at compile time to customize WiX source code (XML) generation.
project.Load
project.BeforeInstall
project.AfterInstall - to be used at runtime (msi execution) to customize deployment behaver.

member.name: M:WixSharp.ManagedProject.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:WixSharp.ManagedProject.#ctor(System.String,WixSharp.WixObject[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The name of the project. Typically it is the name of the product to be installed.
The project installable items (e.g. directories, files, registry keys, Custom Actions).

member.name: P:WixSharp.ManagedProject.MinimalCustomDrawing
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the full or reduced custom drawing algorithm should be used for rendering the Features dialog tree view control. The reduced algorithm involves no manual positioning of the visual elements so it handles better custom screen resolutions. However it also leads to the slightly less intuitive tree view item appearance.
Reduced custom drawing will render disabled tree view items with the text grayed out.
Full custom drawing will render disabled tree view items with the checkbox grayed out.
member.value: true (default) if custom drawing should be reduced otherwise, false.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ManagedProject.SetupEventHandler
member.summary: Event handler of the ManagedSetup for the MSI runtime events.
member.param: The instance containing the event data.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedProject.AbortSetupOnUnhandledExceptions
member.summary:
Indicates if the installations should be aborted if managed event handler throws an unhanded exception.
Aborting is the default behavior if this field is not set.

member.name: E:WixSharp.ManagedProject.UIInitialized
member.summary: Occurs on EmbeddedUI initialized but before the first dialog is displayed. It is only invoked if ManagedUI is set.

member.name: E:WixSharp.ManagedProject.UILoaded
member.summary:
Occurs on EmbeddedUI loaded and ShellView (main window) is displayed but before first dialog is positioned within ShellView. It is only invoked if ManagedUI is set.
Note that this event is fired on the loading the UI main window thus it's not a good stage for any decision regarding aborting/continuing the whole setup process. That is UILoaded event will ignore any value set to SetupEventArgs.Result by the user.

member.name: E:WixSharp.ManagedProject.Load
member.summary: Occurs before AppSearch standard action.

member.name: E:WixSharp.ManagedProject.BeforeInstall
member.summary: Occurs before InstallFiles standard action.

member.name: E:WixSharp.ManagedProject.AfterInstall
member.summary: Occurs after InstallFiles standard action. The event is fired from the elevated execution context.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedProject.ManagedUI
member.summary: An instance of ManagedUI defining MSI UI dialogs sequence. User should set it if he/she wants native MSI dialogs to be replaced by managed ones.

member.name: P:WixSharp.ManagedProject.DefaultDeferredProperties
member.summary:
The default properties mapped for use with the deferred custom actions. See for the details.
The default value is "INSTALLDIR,UILevel"

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedProject.AlwaysScheduleInitRuntime
member.summary:
Flags that indicates if WixSharp_InitRuntime_Action custom action should be always scheduled. The default value is true.
WixSharp_InitRuntime_Action is the action, which ManagedSetup performs at startup (before AppSearch). In this action the most important MSI properties are pushed into Session.CustomActionData. These properties are typically consumed from other custom actions (e.g. Project.AfterInstall event) and they are:
Installed
REMOVE
ProductName
REINSTALL
UPGRADINGPRODUCTCODE
UILevel
WIXSHARP_MANAGED_UI
However in same cases (e.g. oversizes msi file) it is desirable to minimize amount of time the msi loaded into memory (e.g. by custom actions). Thus setting AlwaysScheduleInitRuntime to false will prevent scheduling WixSharp_InitRuntime_Action unless any of the ManagedProject events (e.g. Project.AfterInstall) has user handler assigned.

member.name: P:WixSharp.SetupEventArgs.IsUpgrading
member.summary:
Gets a value indicating whether the installed product is being upgraded.
This property relies on "UPGRADINGPRODUCTCODE" MSI property, which is not set by MSI until previous version is uninstalled. Thus it may not be the most practical way of detecting upgrades. Use AppSearch.GetProductVersionFromUpgradeCode as a more reliable alternative.

member.name: P:WixSharp.SetupEventArgs.Data
member.summary:
Gets or sets the Data.
Data is a free form data storage for custom user defined and Wix# generated settings. In a way it's an alternative to the MSI session properties. The Data is similar to Session as its interface is identical to the Session properties, which is a string dictionary. Though a very important difference is that Data (as opposite to session) does maintain the all entries during the whole MSI session. Even for the deferred action.
Do not confuse `Data` and `Session`. Fist one (Data) keeps user defined custom properties that are available at any stage of setup. Second one (Session) keeps the current MSI session properties and only available for from non-deferred custom actions.
Usage:
Use e.Data for custom action data and copies of MSI properties, so they are available in both deferred and non-deferred actions.
Use e.Session for MSI session properties

member.name: T:WixSharp.Merge
member.summary:
Defines MergeModule to be embedded into MSI.
Note that WiX syntax allows Merge element to belong to the Product element. However the documentation (WiX v3.0.4917.0) explicitly requires it to be nested inside of the Directory element (even if there is no neither technical nor logical reason for this). Thus Wix# simply follows the WiX convention.

member.name: T:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper
member.summary:
Defines native (un-managed) bootstrapper. The primary usage of is to build bootstrappers for automatically installing .NET for executing MSIs containing managed Custom Actions ().
NativeBootstrapper is subject to the following limitations:
Only Win32 native bootstrapper can be built.
Only one Prerequisite cen be defined.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the prerequisite file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrimaryFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the primary setup file.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.PrerequisiteRegKeyValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prerequisite registry key value. This value is used to determine if the should be launched.
This value must comply with the following pattern: <RegistryHive>:<KeyPath>:<ValueName>. PrerequisiteRegKeyValue = @"HKLM:Software\My Company\My Product:Installed"; Existence of the specified registry value at runtime is interpreted as an indication that the has been alreday installed. Thus bootstrapper will execute without launching first.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OutputFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the output file (bootsrtapper) name.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite
member.summary:
Gets or sets the flag which allows you to disable verification of after the prerequisite setup is completed.
Normally if bootstrapper checkes if exists stright after the prerequisite installation and starts the primary setup only if it does.
It is possible to instruct bootstrapper to continue with the primary setup regardless of the prerequisite installation outcome. This can be done by setting DoNotPostVerifyPrerequisite to true (default is false)
member.value: The do not post verify prerequisite.

member.name: P:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.OptionalArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets the optional arguments for the bootstrapper compiler.

member.name: M:WixSharp.NativeBootstrapper.Build
member.summary: Builds bootstrapper file.
member.returns: Path to the built bootstrapper file. Returns null if bootstrapper cannot be built.

member.name: T:WixSharp.Binary
member.summary:
Defines binary file to be embedded into MSI (Binary table).
You can use this class to embed any file (e.g. exe, dll, image) to be used during the installation. Note that none of the binary files are installed on the target system. They are just available at installation time for using CustomActions.
member.example:
The following is an example of embedding CRTSetup.msi file into MSI for further use in InstallCRTAction .
var project = new Project("MyProduct",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File("readme.txt")), ...
new Binary("CRTSetup.msi"), new ManagedAction("InstallCRTAction", ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.EmbeddedAssembly
member.summary:
Defines assembly file to be embedded into MSI (Binary table).
You can use this class to embed any .NET assembly to be used during the installation. Note that none of the binary files are installed on the target system. They are just available at installation time for using CustomActions.
member.example:
The following is an example of embedding CRTSetup.msi file into MSI for further use in InstallCRTAction .
var project = new Project("MyProduct",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"readme.txt")), ...
new EmbeddedAssembly("config.exe") { RefAssemblies = new [] { "utils.dll" }}, new ManagedAction("InstallCRTAction", ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions
member.summary: This class holds the settings for Wix# XML auto-generation: generation of WiX XML elements, which do not have direct representation in the Wix# script. The detailed information about Wix# auto-generation can be found here: http://www.csscript.net/WixSharp/ID_Allocation.html.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.InstallDirDefaultId
member.summary:
The ID of the root directory, which is automatically assigned to the first directory of the project directories.
The default value "INSTALLDIR" has special meaning as apart from being a traditional choice of the id for the root directory it is also used in binding root directory to the textbox of the InstallDirDialog.
It is important to have the id as public (upper case). Otherwise WiX doesn't produce correct MSI.
The auto-assignment can be disabled by setting InstallDirDefaultId to null.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.Map64InstallDirs
member.summary: Flag indicating if all system folders (e.g. %ProgramFiles%) should be auto-mapped into their x64 equivalents when 'project.Platform = Platform.x64'

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.IsWxsGenerationThreadSafe
member.summary:
Forces the WXS to be thread-safe. Default value is false.
If this field is useful when WixShar accesses some shared resources during WXS generation. For example: using that uses project's "target path resolver" during multiple concurrent builds.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.CustomIdAlgorithm
member.summary: The custom algorithm for generating WiX elements IDs.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.LegacyDefaultIdAlgorithm
member.summary: The legacy default identifier algorithm

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.ForceComponentIdUniqueness
member.summary: Force Component ID uniqueness.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.IgnoreWildCardEmptyDirectories
member.summary: The ignore empty directories during wild card resolution

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.ValidateCAAssemblies
member.summary:
Enable validating CA assemblies for all CA methods to be public instance method.
By default validation is performed in a temporary AppDomain (`CAValidation.InRemoteAppDomain`) as it is the only way to avoid locking the assembly being validated. Unfortunately `ReflectionOnlyLoadFrom` is incompatible with this task as it does not allow browsing members attributes.
You may need to disable (`CAValidation.Disabled`) the validation if WixSharp is hosted on the runtime that does not support AppDomain unloading (e.g. .NET Core)
If you want to perform validation without the use of temporary AppDomain you can chose the `CAValidation.InCurrentAppDomain` option. In this case the assembly being validated is loaded in the current AppDomain but from the memory without locking the assembly file. This option is valid but not recommended as it may lead to the unpredictable reflection scenarios.

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.SuppressForBundlePayloadUndefinedIds
member.summary: The suppress generation of the XML attribute 'id' for undefined ids

member.name: F:WixSharp.AutoGenerationOptions.HashedTargetPathIdAlgorithm_FileIdMask
member.summary:
The template for auto-generated File id.
The default value is "{file_name}_{dir_hash}".

member.name: T:WixSharp.Condition
member.summary:
Defines WiX Condition. Condition is normally associated with CustomActions or WiX elements (e.g. Shortcut).
is nothing else but an XML friendly string wrapper, containing some predefined (commonly used) condition values. You can either use one of the predefined condition values (static members) or define your by specifying full string representation of the required WiX condition when calling the constructor or static method Create.
member.example:
The following is an example of initializing the Shortcut. with custom value INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT="yes" and the InstalledFileAction. with perefined value NOT_Installed:
var project = new Project("My Product", ... new Dir(@"%Desktop%", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", "[INSTALLDIR]MyApp.exe", "") { Condition = new Condition("INSTALLDESKTOPSHORTCUT=\"yes\"") }), new InstalledFileAction("MyApp.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.Dir
member.summary:
Defines directory to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define file/directory structure of the deployment solution.
You can use predefined Wix# environment constants for well-known installation locations. They are directly mapped to the corresponding WiX constants:
For the full list of the constants consult WiX documentation or use Compiler.GetMappedWixConstants to explore them programmatically./
Wix# - WiX
%WindowsFolder% - [WindowsFolder]
%ProgramFiles% - [ProgramFilesFolder]
%ProgramMenu% - [ProgramMenuFolder]
%CommonAppDataFolder% - [CommonAppDataFolder]
%AppDataFolder% - [AppDataFolder]
%CommonFilesFolder% - [CommonFilesFolder]
%LocalAppDataFolder% - [LocalAppDataFolder]
%ProgramFiles64Folder% - [ProgramFiles64Folder]
%System64Folder% - [System64Folder]
%SystemFolder% - [SystemFolder]
%TempFolder% - [TempFolder]
%Desktop% - [DesktopFolder]
...

Wix# assigns a dedicated WiX UI property WIXUI_INSTALLDIR to the Id value of the directory, which is marked by user as or the directory with the designated Dir Id value defined by Compiler.AutoGeneration.InstallDirDefaultId ('INSTALLDIR' by default).

member.name: T:WixSharp.InstallDir
member.summary:
Defines directory to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define file/directory structure of the deployment solution. You can use predefined Wix# environment constants for well-known installation locations. They are directly mapped to the corresponding WiX constants:
For the full list of the constants consult WiX documentation or use Compiler.GetMappedWixConstants to explore them programatically./
Wix# - WiX
%WindowsFolder% - [WindowsFolder]
%ProgramFiles% - [ProgramFilesFolder]
%ProgramMenu% - [ProgramMenuFolder]
%CommonAppDataFolder% - [CommonAppDataFolder]
%AppDataFolder% - [AppDataFolder]
%CommonFilesFolder% - [CommonFilesFolder]
%LocalAppDataFolder% - [LocalAppDataFolder]
%ProgramFiles64Folder% - [ProgramFiles64Folder]
%System64Folder% - [System64Folder]
%SystemFolder% - [SystemFolder]
%TempFolder% - [TempFolder]
%Desktop% - [DesktopFolder]
...
class is identical to except it already has IsInstallDir set to true so it is more convenient for defining your installation directory.
member.example:
The following is an example of defining installation directory Progam Files/My Company/My Product containing a single file MyApp.exe and subdirectory Documentation with UserManual.pdf file.
var project = new Project("MyProduct", new InstallDir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"Release\MyApp.exe"), new Dir("Documentation", new File(@"Release\UserManual.pdf")), ...

members.member:
Defines all files of a given source directory and all subdirectories to be installed on target system.
Use this class to define files to be automatically included into the deployment solution if their name matches specified wildcard character pattern ().
This class is a logical equivalent of except it also analyses all files in all subdirectories. excludes files in subdirectories.
You can control inclusion of empty directories during wild card resolving by adjusting the compiler setting Compiler.AutoGeneration.IgnoreWildCardEmptyDirectories.
Note that all files matching wildcard are resolved into absolute path thus it may not always be suitable if the Wix# script is to be compiled into WiX XML source only (Compiler.). Though it is not a problem at all if the Wix# script is compiled into MSI file (Compiler.). b The following is an example of defining installation files with wildcard character pattern.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\MyCompany\MyProduct", new Files(@"Release\Bin\*.*"), ...

member.name: M:WixSharp.Files.FromBuildDir(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Aggregates the files from the build directory. It is nothing else but a simplified creation of the as below:
new Files(buildDir.PathJoin("*.*"), f => f.EndsWithAny(ignoreCase: true, new[]{".exe",".dll,".xml",".config", ".json"}))
member.param: The file extensions to match the files that need to be included in the deployment.

Initializes a new instance of the class with properties/fields initialized with specified parameters.
You can control inclusion of empty folders (if picked by the wild card patter) by setting to true.
If more specific control is required you can always use a flat list of Dirs of the Project. to remove the undesired folder from its parent collection.

member.name: M:WixSharp.LocalizationExtensions.BuildMultilanguageMsi(WixSharp.Project,WixSharp.ProjectLocalization,WixSharp.ProjectLocalization[])
member.summary: Produces multilanguage MSI with embedded transformations based on collection. If this msi is executed on the OS, which language matches one of the embedded transformations, this transformation will be automatically triggered and effectively switch the setup UI language. Builds the localized msi.
member.param: Use your OS language as default localization. This will ensure that the all transformations are embedded in such a way that the produced msi can switch to any alternative language both automatically and manually.
Collection of localizations. At least one localization is expected.

member.name: M:WixSharp.LocalizationExtensions.BuildMultilanguageMsi(WixSharp.Project,System.String)
member.summary:
Builds the localized msi.
This method builds the msi with the default language support according `project.Language` setting. The additional languages can also be embedded into the resulting msi during the build.
Invoking specific language UI is triggered either automatically based on the OS default language or by passing special MSI properties arguments to the msiexec.exe:
English
msiexec /i setup.msi
German
msiexec /i setup.msi TRANSFORMS=:1031
Russian
msiexec /i setup.msi TRANSFORMS=:1049

member.name: M:WixSharp.LocalizationExtensions.IsCompatibleWith(System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Determines whether two cultures are compatible based on the same neutral culture (e.g. en-US is compatible with en-AU).
member.returns: true if [is compatible with] [the specified info2]; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:WixSharp.LocalizationExtensions.VerifyLanguage(WixSharp.Project)
member.summary: Verifies the language of the multi-language project being compatible with the language of the operating system the project is being built on. The compatibility is important in this case as the wrong choice of the default language can lead to the problems when building bootstrapper with the language selection. See "<root>\Source\src\WixSharp.Samples\Wix# Samples\Bootstrapper\MultiLanguageSupport\setup.cs> sample.

member.name: F:WixSharp.File.OverwriteOnInstall
member.summary:
Controls if an existing file should be overwritten during the installation. By default MSI runtime does not install the file if it already exists at the deployment destination on the target system. This field allows changing this behaviour and ensuring that a file installed always even when existed prior the installation.
If this field is set to true the WixSharp injects the following element into the file's parent component. <RemoveFile Id="Remove_Filetxt" Name="File.txt" On="install" />

Gets or sets the NeverOverwrite attribute of the associated WiX component.
If this attribute is set to 'true', the installer does not install or reinstall the component if a key path file for the component already exists.

member.name: F:WixSharp.File.AddCloseAction
member.summary:
The flag that indicates if CloseApplication needs to be added for the specified file.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"..\Install Files\Files\Bin\MyApp.exe") { AddCloseAction = true }), ...
// the code above is equivalent of code below
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", new File(@"..\Install Files\Files\Bin\MyApp.exe"), new CloseApplication("MyApp.exe", true, false)), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.DirFiles
member.summary:
Defines files of a given source directory to be installed on target system. Note that files in subdirectories are not included.
Use this class to define files to be automatically included into the deployment solution if their name matches specified wildcard character pattern ().
This class is a logical equivalent of except that it analyses files in a single directory.
member.remarks: Note that all files matching the wildcard are resolved into absolute paths, so it may not always be suitable if the Wix# script is to be compiled into WiX XML source only (Compiler.). This is not a problem if the Wix# script is compiled into MSI file (Compiler.).
member.example:
The following is an example of defining installation files with a wildcard character pattern.
new Project("MyProduct", new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\MyCompany\MyProduct", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\*.*"), new Dir("GlobalResources", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\GlobalResources\*.*")), new Dir("Images", new DirFiles(@"Release\Bin\Images\*.*")), ...

member.name: T:WixSharp.InstalledFileAction
member.summary: Defines WiX InstalledFileAction for executing installed file.
member.example:
The following is an example of using InstalledFileAction to run installed executable Registrator.exe with different arguments depending in installation type (install/uninstall):
var project = new Project("My Product",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product",
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\MyApp.exe", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product"), new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%Desktop%")),
new File(binaries, @"AppFiles\Registrator.exe"),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "", Return.check, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed),
new InstalledFileAction("Registrator.exe", "/u", Return.check, When.Before, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.Installed), ...
Compiler.BuildMsi(project);

member.name: T:WixSharp.CustomActionMethod
member.summary: Method delegate implementing WiX CustomAction.

member.name: T:WixSharp.ManagedAction
member.summary:
Defines WiX Managed CustomAction.
Managed CustomAction can be defined either in the Wix# script or in the external assembly or C# file. The only requirements for any C# method to be qualified for being Managed CustomAcyion is to have DTF Action signature public static ActionResult MyManagedAction(Session session), and be marked with [CustomAction] attribute.
If Managed CustomAction depends on any assembly, which will not be registered with GAC on the target system such assembly needs to be listed in the .
often needs to be executed with the elevated privileges. Thus after instantiation it will have set to false and set to Execute.deferred to allow elevating.

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedAction.MethodName

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedAction.UsesProperties
member.summary:
Comma separated list of properties which the custom action is intended to use. Set this property if you are implementing the 'deferred' (as well as 'rollback' and 'commit') action.
Deferred custom actions cannot access any session property as the session is terminated at the time of the action execution (limitation of MSI). The standard way of overcoming this limitation is to create a new custom action for setting the property, set the property name to the name of the deferred action, set the property value to the specially formatted map, schedule the execution of the custom action and access the mapped properties only via .
All this can be done in a single hit with Wix# as it fully automates creation of the all mapping infrastructure.

remarks.para: Note that you don't even have to specify UsesProperties = "INSTALLDIR" as by default Wix# always maps INSTALLDIR and UILevel for all deferred managed actions. The default mapping is controlled by .
It is also possible to map the 'deferred' properties in the typical WiX way:

member.name: F:WixSharp.ManagedAction.DefaultUsesProperties
member.summary:
The default properties mapped for use with the 'deferred' (as well as 'rollback' and 'commit') custom actions. See for the details.
The default value is "INSTALLDIR,UILevel,ProductCode,ADDLOCAL,ADDFEATURES"

member.name: T:WixSharp.PathFileAction
member.summary: Defines WiX CustomAction for executing file specified by the path on the target system.
member.example:
The following is an example of using PathFileAction to run executable present on the target system (Notepad.exe):
var project = new Project("My Product",
new Dir(@"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product",
new File(@"AppFiles\MyApp.exe", new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%ProgramMenu%\My Company\My Product"), new WixSharp.Shortcut("MyApp", @"%Desktop%")),
new File(@"AppFiles\Readme.txt"),
new PathFileAction(@"%WindowsFolder%\notepad.exe", "Readme.txt", @"%ProgramFiles%\My Company\My Product", Return.asyncNoWait, When.After, Step.InstallFinalize, Condition.NOT_Installed), ...
Compiler.BuildMsi(project);

The REINSTALLMODE property is a string that contains letters specifying the type of reinstall to perform. Options are case-insensitive and order-independent. This property should normally always be used in conjunction with the REINSTALL property.
Note, REINSTALLMODE property will be created only in the automatically produced WiX definition file only if is set.
Read more: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/msi/reinstallmode

member.summary: Simplifies authoring for major upgrades, including support for preventing downgrades.

member.name: F:WixSharp.Project.UpgradeCode
member.summary:
This is the value of the UpgradeCode attribute of the Wix Product element.
Both WiX and MSI consider this element as optional even it is the only available identifier for defining relationship between different versions of the same product. Wix# in contrary enforces that value to allow any future updates of the product being installed.
If user doesn't specify this value Wix# engine will use as UpgradeCode.

member.name: P:WixSharp.Project.GUID
member.summary:
This value uniquely identifies the software product being installed.
All setup build scripts for different versions of the same product should have the same . If user doesn't specify this value Wix# engine will generate new random GUID for it.
This value should not be confused with MSI ProductId, which is in fact not an identifier of the product but rather an identifier of the product particular version. MSI uses UpgradeCode as a common identification of the product regardless of it's version.
In a way is an alias for .
